div.l: Sike lay the maunciple / on a maladie
Men wenden wisly / that he shulde dye
For which this Miller͗e / stale both mele ⁊and corn̄
An hundred tyme more / than biforn̄
For ther biforn̄ / he stal but curteysly
But now he was a theff / outrageously
For which the wardeyn / chidde ⁊and made fare
But therof sette the Miller / nought a tare
He crakede bost ⁊and swore / it was nought so
Than were there / yonge scolers two
That dwelten / in the halle / of which I seye
Testiff thei were / ⁊and lusty for to pleye
And oonly for here merthe / ⁊and reuelrie
Vppon the wardeyn / besily thei crie
To yeve hem leve / but a litel stounde
To go to mylle / ⁊and seen here corn̄ I grounde
And hardly thei durste / ley here nekke
The Miller shulde not / stele hem halff a pekke
Of corn / ne bi sleight / ne bi force hem reve
And at the last / the wardeyn yaff hem leve
¶ Iohn hight that oon / ⁊and Aleyn hight that other
Of oon town̄ were thei born̄ / that hight Strother
Fer in the northe / I can nought telle where
This Aleyn makith redy / al his gere
And on an hors / the sak he cast anoon
Forth goth Aleyn the clerc / ⁊and also Iohn
With good swerde ⁊and bokeler / bi here side
Iohn knewe the wey / him neded no gide
And at the Mille / the sak adoun̄ he layth
Aleyn spak first / al hail symon̄ in fayth
How fares thi faire dought̉er ⁊and thi wiff
Aleyn welcome / qduod symkyn bi my liff
And Iohn also / how now / what do ye here
Bigod qduod Iohn / Symond nede has no pere
Him bihoves s̉erue him silff / that has no swayn
Or ellis he is a fool / as clerkes sayn
